programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: tiny desk concerts JAPAN
programme.desc: Horigome Yasuyuki , formerly of the acclaimed band KIRINJI, appears on tiny desk concerts JAPAN Joined by guest vocalist Toki Asako, he performs Aliens, a timeless masterpiece in J-POP history. Featuring a pedal steel guitar, this tiny desk original band arrangement beautifully enhances the lyrical richness and depth of his music. In the intimate setting of the NHK office, the meticulous ensemble and the duo's harmonizing vocals shed new light on the classic track's enduring appeal. Enjoy this exclusive 30-minute session, available only here.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: In recent years, a sense of nostalgia has been spreading among young people in Japan for the Showa era, which lasted from 1926 to 1989. A theme park has opened a recreation of a 1960s shopping street. Radio-cassette players and colorful retro designs are once again popular. And long-established cafes serve recipes that haven't changed in decades. We introduce some of the cultural elements defining an era that many Japanese people consider the "good old days."

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Gunma: Kusatsu Onsen and Daruma Dolls
programme.desc: Kotaro lives in an inn in Kusatsu Onsen and shows us around the popular hot spring town. Meanwhile, Mike lives in a store in Takasaki City that sells daruma dolls. She keeps the staff company.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: Intertwined Lives on Sea and Shore: Shiretoko, Hokkaido
programme.desc: The Shiretoko Peninsula, located in eastern Hokkaido Prefecture, juts into the Sea of Okhotsk. Its center is lined by 1,500-meter peaks. The heavily forested area is home to a diverse group of animals, including the Blakiston's fish owl, which is at imminent risk of extinction. Shiretoko's waters are home to creatures who feed off the bounty of floating pack ice. Explore an extraordinary ecosystem which connects the rich environments of both land and sea.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: Okinawa Prefecture is a group of subtropical islands in the far south of Japan. We examine its past and present, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time: US Influences.

programme.title: RAMEN JAPAN
programme.desc: Savor a rare beef-bone broth ramen! And try a strikingly simple local ramen that overturns expectations boldly.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Zuiki Matsuri: A Celebration of the Local Harvests
programme.desc: Kitano Tenmangu shrine holds the Zuiki Matsuri festival over 5 days in early October. Sacred palanquins carry the spirit of Sugawara no Michizane, who was a scholar and politician over 1,000 years ago, through the parish to its temporary abode. Residents spend a month festooning one float, that has a 400-year history, with local produce and imbue it with gratitude for an abundant harvest. Discover this festival that retains vestiges of bygone days when the district was a farming area.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: This episode is about expressing an opinion concisely. Tomanik, from Poland, got serious about studying Japanese and then he fell in love with Japanese pop culture. Although he can explain himself in meetings in Japanese just fine, he tends to make very long explanations. By role-playing and receiving guidance from experts, he'll learn how to express himself more directly.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Repurposing used wine corks, old clothing... even eggshells into interior design materials, upcycling expert Miura Seiya is in high demand with companies looking for ways to reduce their waste.

programme.title: Unsolved Cases
programme.sub-title: How Land Swindlers Deceived a Housing Giant
programme.desc: In 2017, a Japanese housing giant was tricked out of $50 million by land swindlers. How did the firm fail to detect the scam? We delve into the nature of the elusive network that shook the nation.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Explore the Tokyo National Museum
programme.desc: The Tokyo National Museum is home to a collection of some 120,000 objects of beauty and interest, mainly Japanese art and craft pieces along with work from the Asian mainland and historical artifacts. The museum houses 89 items deemed by the Japanese government to be of especially high value and designated as national treasures. Paying a visit to this historic museum that is celebrating its 150th anniversary are Andy and Shaula, hosts of NHK WORLD-JAPAN’s popular program DESIGN TALKS plus. They marvel at the majestic building, visit an exhibit that offers insights into 30,000 years of creativity in Japan, and revel in the first ever exhibit of every national treasure in the museum’s possession — an experience that will surely make art aficionados across the world jealous. The two also get a glimpse of the future of museums, experiencing high-definition imagery, 3D computer graphics, and other cutting-edge digital technology. Come join us on this 50-minute adventure exploring the Tokyo National Museum, something not to be missed by anyone visiting the metropolis.

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: This episode spotlights next-generation creator Yamashita Shingo, known for his key animation work on NARUTO SHIPPUDEN and opening direction for JUJUTSU KAISEN. Plus, we follow Yamashita behind the scenes as he directs his new feature film, Cosmic Princess Kaguya! See how he blends cutting-edge tools with a fresh creative vision to craft anime.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: Rocco likes to tag along with his big sister Rockie, but one day Rockie leaves him out from the play group, saying he is too small to join. Then Rocco goes missing. Educational theme: Generosity and sympathy.

programme.title: Texico
programme.desc: Learn the principles of programming without even touching a computer in this new-style education program. Unique animated characters assist in the fun and lucid introduction of 5 core programming processes: analysis, combination, generalization, abstraction and simulation.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.desc: Climate change has begun to impact the food supply. In Japan, hotter summers and stronger typhoons are affecting rice. Researchers are now working to develop rice that can withstand such challenges.

programme.desc: Shimane Prefecture / Fukasawa Naoto (Product designer) Red "Sekishu" roof tiles are perfectly suited to cold, snowy regions. Fukasawa considers design that embodies the community it comes from.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: A Nankai Trough megaquake is expected to cause severe damage. In this episode, we will examine how Japan is preparing for this impending disaster with cutting-edge technology.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode introduces words related to ashi, which means both foot and leg. They have many important pressure points and play a significant role in blood flow. They've even been called the "second heart." We follow poet, literary translator and long-time Japan resident Peter MacMillan as he takes a walk around his home in Kyoto Prefecture. He guides us through unique words and expressions along the way.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.desc: When you see something for the first time and want to know what it is, just ask "kore wa nan desu ka."

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.desc: RAMUNE, a descendant of Japanese emigrants to Brazil, is a performer of rakugo, Japan's traditional storytelling. Performing in multiple languages, she helps foreigners experience Japanese culture.

programme.sub-title: Introducing Multilingual Services at the Embassy of Bangladesh
programme.desc: With multilingual services, NHK WORLD-JAPAN helps foreign residents with disaster prevention and daily life. A presentation introducing these services was given at the Embassy of Bangladesh, in Tokyo.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Awaji Island: Mythical Birthplace of Japan
programme.desc: Awaji Island is the largest island in the Seto Inland Sea. From ancient times, Awaji has been known as "Japan's Foodstore," and local fish have, down the years, been presented to the Imperial Court. The island is also proud of its connection to the legend of the two gods, Izanagi and Izanami, who gave birth to Japan. The story of Japan's origins describes how the gods passed the country on to the people. Awaji Island is where it all began.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Darwin's Amazing Animals
programme.desc: The dry season is a desperate time in the African savanna. Herds of wild animals join great migrations in search of food and water. But that's not always the case for the lucky ones in Tanzania's Ruaha National Park. An incredible symbiotic relationship has formed between animals and plants, resulting in a year-round home for all. Our team travels to the 20,000-square-kilometer nature reserve in East Africa to discover what makes Ruaha National Park such a wondrous paradise.

programme.title: Time-lapse Journey
programme.desc: Nikko, in Tochigi Prefecture, is home to much natural beauty with its great mountains and lakes. Located at a convenient distance from Tokyo, many come to escape from the summer heat. The ornate Nikko Toshogu Shrine is a popular spiritual place. See the widely beloved Nikko through time-lapse photography.

programme.desc: Join us on a night flight to admire Japan's stunning views on a journey from Tokyo to Fukuoka Prefecture. Behold the sublime beauty of Mt. Fuji at sunset and the sparkling night views of major cities.

programme.title: RAMEN JAPAN
programme.desc: Two local takes on ramen that kept Hiroshima Prefecture fed during postwar reconstruction; flavors passed down for generations.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: Japan is a seismically active land; the Edo period was no exception. In the aftermath of a major 1855 earthquake, an angry guardian deity sets off on a quest to capture those considered responsible.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Have You Written by Hand Lately? — The Value of Handwriting in the Digital Age
programme.desc: As the world continues to shift from handwriting to digital input, in Japan, an increasing number of people are forgetting how to write some kanji characters by hand. Recent studies show handwriting can help stimulate the brain and prevent cognitive decline. Indeed, schools in countries like Sweden and the United States are allocating more time on classes where students learn through writing by hand. With our guests, we explore the value of handwriting in this digital age. Guests: Itoi Shigesato (Copywriter) Otsuka Sadao (Associate Professor, Hyogo University of Teacher Education)

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Awaji Island: Mythical Birthplace of Japan
programme.desc: Awaji Island is the largest island in the Seto Inland Sea. From ancient times, Awaji has been known as "Japan's Foodstore," and local fish have, down the years, been presented to the Imperial Court. The island is also proud of its connection to the legend of the two gods, Izanagi and Izanami, who gave birth to Japan. The story of Japan's origins describes how the gods passed the country on to the people. Awaji Island is where it all began.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.sub-title: HAGI: Vessels That Age with You
programme.desc: *First broadcast on January 26, 2026 Hagi ware has been cherished in tea ceremonies for over 400 years. Cracks in the glaze create patterns whose color evolves with time and use. Watch masterful pottery production in time-lapse.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode introduces words related to ashi, which means both foot and leg. They have many important pressure points and play a significant role in blood flow. They've even been called the "second heart." We follow poet, literary translator and long-time Japan resident Peter MacMillan as he takes a walk around his home in Kyoto Prefecture. He guides us through unique words and expressions along the way.

programme.title: Easy Japanese
programme.desc: When you see something for the first time and want to know what it is, just ask "kore wa nan desu ka."

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.desc: RAMUNE, a descendant of Japanese emigrants to Brazil, is a performer of rakugo, Japan's traditional storytelling. Performing in multiple languages, she helps foreigners experience Japanese culture.

programme.sub-title: Introducing Multilingual Services at the Embassy of Bangladesh
programme.desc: With multilingual services, NHK WORLD-JAPAN helps foreign residents with disaster prevention and daily life. A presentation introducing these services was given at the Embassy of Bangladesh, in Tokyo.

programme.title: Hometown Stories

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.desc: Hello there! It's me, Tama. Don't mind me, I just saw a hole and wanted to cool my paws in it. Looks like Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are preparing their annual dried persimmons. So tasty! So sweet! But it takes weeks before they're ready! I don't know if I can wait that long!

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Taketa: Onsen Bathing Old and New
programme.desc: People in Japan love bathing in hot springs, or onsen. And since the old days, it has been common for people to check into residential hot-spring inns for extended stays to boost their health, heal their aches and regain their well-being. This style of onsen therapeutics is known as Tōji. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Kyle Card travels to Taketa City in Oita Prefecture to discover a contemporary style of Tōji therapy where visitors can recover their energy while enjoying the majestic natural environment along with some of the world's finest carbonated hot springs.

programme.title: Darwin's Amazing Animals
programme.desc: The dry season is a desperate time in the African savanna. Herds of wild animals join great migrations in search of food and water. An incredible symbiotic relationship has formed between animals and plants, resulting in a year-round home for all. Our team travels to the 20,000-square-kilometer nature reserve in East Africa to discover what makes Ruaha National Park such a wondrous paradise.

programme.title: Explore the Tokyo National Museum
programme.desc: The Tokyo National Museum is home to a collection of some 120,000 objects of beauty and interest, mainly Japanese art and craft pieces along with work from the Asian mainland and historical artifacts. The museum houses 89 items deemed by the Japanese government to be of especially high value and designated as national treasures. Paying a visit to this historic museum that is celebrating its 150th anniversary are Andy and Shaula, hosts of NHK WORLD-JAPAN’s popular program DESIGN TALKS plus. They marvel at the majestic building, visit an exhibit that offers insights into 30,000 years of creativity in Japan, and revel in the first ever exhibit of every national treasure in the museum’s possession — an experience that will surely make art aficionados across the world jealous. The two also get a glimpse of the future of museums, experiencing high-definition imagery, 3D computer graphics, and other cutting-edge digital technology. Come join us on this 50-minute adventure exploring the Tokyo National Museum, something not to be missed by anyone visiting the metropolis.

programme.title: tiny desk concerts JAPAN
programme.desc: Horigome Yasuyuki , formerly of the acclaimed band KIRINJI, appears on tiny desk concerts JAPAN Joined by guest vocalist Toki Asako, he performs Aliens, a timeless masterpiece in J-POP history. Featuring a pedal steel guitar, this tiny desk original band arrangement beautifully enhances the lyrical richness and depth of his music. In the intimate setting of the NHK office, the meticulous ensemble and the duo's harmonizing vocals shed new light on the classic track's enduring appeal. Enjoy this exclusive 30-minute session, available only here.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: In recent years, a sense of nostalgia has been spreading among young people in Japan for the Showa era, which lasted from 1926 to 1989. A theme park has opened a recreation of a 1960s shopping street. Radio-cassette players and colorful retro designs are once again popular. And long-established cafes serve recipes that haven't changed in decades. We introduce some of the cultural elements defining an era that many Japanese people consider the "good old days."

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Gunma: Kusatsu Onsen and Daruma Dolls

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: Intertwined Lives on Sea and Shore: Shiretoko, Hokkaido
programme.desc: The Shiretoko Peninsula, located in eastern Hokkaido Prefecture, juts into the Sea of Okhotsk. Its center is lined by 1,500-meter peaks. The heavily forested area is home to a diverse group of animals, including the Blakiston's fish owl, which is at imminent risk of extinction. Shiretoko's waters are home to creatures who feed off the bounty of floating pack ice. Explore an extraordinary ecosystem which connects the rich environments of both land and sea.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Zuiki Matsuri: A Celebration of the Local Harvests
programme.desc: Kitano Tenmangu shrine holds the Zuiki Matsuri festival over 5 days in early October. Sacred palanquins carry the spirit of Sugawara no Michizane, who was a scholar and politician over 1,000 years ago, through the parish to its temporary abode. Residents spend a month festooning one float, that has a 400-year history, with local produce and imbue it with gratitude for an abundant harvest. Discover this festival that retains vestiges of bygone days when the district was a farming area.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: This episode is about expressing an opinion concisely. Tomanik, from Poland, got serious about studying Japanese and then he fell in love with Japanese pop culture. Although he can explain himself in meetings in Japanese just fine, he tends to make very long explanations. By role-playing and receiving guidance from experts, he'll learn how to express himself more directly.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Repurposing used wine corks, old clothing... even eggshells into interior design materials, upcycling expert Miura Seiya is in high demand with companies looking for ways to reduce their waste.

programme.title: Unsolved Cases
programme.sub-title: How Land Swindlers Deceived a Housing Giant
programme.desc: In 2017, a Japanese housing giant was tricked out of $50 million by land swindlers. How did the firm fail to detect the scam? We delve into the nature of the elusive network that shook the nation.

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: Intertwined Lives on Sea and Shore: Shiretoko, Hokkaido
programme.desc: The Shiretoko Peninsula, located in eastern Hokkaido Prefecture, juts into the Sea of Okhotsk. Its center is lined by 1,500-meter peaks. The heavily forested area is home to a diverse group of animals, including the Blakiston's fish owl, which is at imminent risk of extinction. Shiretoko's waters are home to creatures who feed off the bounty of floating pack ice. Explore an extraordinary ecosystem which connects the rich environments of both land and sea.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: Okinawa Prefecture is a group of subtropical islands in the far south of Japan. We examine its past and present, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time: US Influences.

programme.title: GRAND SUMO LIVE
programme.desc: NHK WORLD-JAPAN will broadcast GRAND SUMO January Tournament Day 15 action live from Tokyo, as top wrestlers have their fifteenth bouts of the 15-day contest.

programme.desc: Rocco likes to tag along with his big sister Rockie, but one day Rockie leaves him out from the play group, saying he is too small to join. Then Rocco goes missing. Educational theme: Generosity and sympathy.

programme.title: tiny desk concerts JAPAN
programme.desc: Horigome Yasuyuki , formerly of the acclaimed band KIRINJI, appears on tiny desk concerts JAPAN Joined by guest vocalist Toki Asako, he performs Aliens, a timeless masterpiece in J-POP history. Featuring a pedal steel guitar, this tiny desk original band arrangement beautifully enhances the lyrical richness and depth of his music. In the intimate setting of the NHK office, the meticulous ensemble and the duo's harmonizing vocals shed new light on the classic track's enduring appeal. Enjoy this exclusive 30-minute session, available only here.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: In recent years, a sense of nostalgia has been spreading among young people in Japan for the Showa era, which lasted from 1926 to 1989. A theme park has opened a recreation of a 1960s shopping street. Radio-cassette players and colorful retro designs are once again popular. And long-established cafes serve recipes that haven't changed in decades. We introduce some of the cultural elements defining an era that many Japanese people consider the "good old days."

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Gunma: Kusatsu Onsen and Daruma Dolls
programme.desc: Kotaro lives in an inn in Kusatsu Onsen and shows us around the popular hot spring town. Meanwhile, Mike lives in a store in Takasaki City that sells daruma dolls. She keeps the staff company.

programme.title: Explore the Tokyo National Museum
programme.desc: The Tokyo National Museum is home to a collection of some 120,000 objects of beauty and interest, mainly Japanese art and craft pieces along with work from the Asian mainland and historical artifacts. The museum houses 89 items deemed by the Japanese government to be of especially high value and designated as national treasures. Paying a visit to this historic museum that is celebrating its 150th anniversary are Andy and Shaula, hosts of NHK WORLD-JAPAN’s popular program DESIGN TALKS plus. They marvel at the majestic building, visit an exhibit that offers insights into 30,000 years of creativity in Japan, and revel in the first ever exhibit of every national treasure in the museum’s possession — an experience that will surely make art aficionados across the world jealous. The two also get a glimpse of the future of museums, experiencing high-definition imagery, 3D computer graphics, and other cutting-edge digital technology. Come join us on this 50-minute adventure exploring the Tokyo National Museum, something not to be missed by anyone visiting the metropolis.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Taketa: Onsen Bathing Old and New
programme.desc: People in Japan love bathing in hot springs, or onsen. And since the old days, it has been common for people to check into residential hot-spring inns for extended stays to boost their health, heal their aches and regain their well-being. This style of onsen therapeutics is known as Tōji. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Kyle Card travels to Taketa City in Oita Prefecture to discover a contemporary style of Tōji therapy where visitors can recover their energy while enjoying the majestic natural environment along with some of the world's finest carbonated hot springs.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Adapting Anime Costumes for Live-Action: Nakahara Sachiko / Stylist and Costume Designer
programme.desc: Nakahara Sachiko translates the looks of popular Japanese anime and manga characters into costumes for live-action adaptations. She talks about making an impact on the global stage.

programme.title: Nun's Seasonal Calendar
programme.desc: Join us as we learn about life at the Otowasan Kannonji Temple through 24 terms from the solar calendar. First, we follow the nuns on the day of Risshun. They enjoy colorful neko-mochi rice cakes, creating unique variations by adding unusual ingredients. Then they celebrate Girls' Day with a special tea ceremony on the day of Usui.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: A Napping Boy Dreams of Monsters
programme.desc: When a little boy's nap is disturbed by a bad dream, his mother comes to his rescue. What was terrorizing him? We examine a print that shows how much the Edo townspeople cherished their kids.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Aging Well: The Most Private Challenge
programme.desc: Japanese people are increasingly living longer lives, but the change is not always a welcome one. For many, the progression into old age, and the accompanying decline in bodily functions, results in continence issues. Many are reluctant to acknowledge the problem or accept outside help on such an intensely private matter. We asked experts how carers and loved ones can support people dealing with toileting issues, and consider how the elderly themselves can embrace a positive shift in perspective to get the most out of their final stage of life. Guests: Gondo Yasuyuki (Professor, Graduate School of Human Sciences, The University of Osaka), Urata Katsumi (Certified Nurse in Wound, Ostomy and Continence Nursing with Advanced Practice Authorization)

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: At a Huge Thrift Store in Saitama
programme.desc: Bargain-hunters and people decluttering their homes flock to a huge thrift store near Tokyo. For three days, we asked customers what drew them to this place filled with an array of second-hand goods.
